results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to investigate synthetic data generation for Learning Analytics, comparing LLMs and GANs. The methodology is outlined in the introduction and further detailed in Section 3.

Section 3 provides a detailed pipeline (Figure 1) outlining the steps: datasets description, environment setup, synthetic data generation, and evaluation. Each step is further elaborated in subsequent subsections.

The document states: "all the generated synthetic data by the four generative models CTGAN, GPT2, DistilGPT2, and DialoGPT as well as the evaluation results can be accessed via the GitHub repository 5."

While the document mentions using existing datasets (UCI, Open University, MOOC, eLearning), it doesn't explicitly state if *those* datasets are publicly available. It focuses on the availability of the *generated* data.
Table 1 provides a description of the datasets used, including the number of attributes, records, target variable, and data types. Section 3.1 provides further details on each dataset.
The document does not detail the original data collection methods for the datasets used (e.g., how the UCI student performance data was collected). It only describes the datasets themselves.

The document states: "all the generated synthetic data by the four generative models CTGAN, GPT2, DistilGPT2, and DialoGPT as well as the evaluation results can be accessed via the GitHub repository 5."
There is no explicit justification for *not* sharing the code, but the document doesn't state whether all code is shared, only that results and generated data are available on GitHub.
The document states that preprocessing steps were performed and that the code is available in the GitHub repository.
The document describes statistical tests (Chi-squared test), models (XGBoost, Random Forest, KNN, Decision Tree, GANs, LLMs), and their application in evaluating synthetic data.
The document reports effect sizes (e.g., WD, JSD), and mentions AUCROC, F1-score, and Accuracy as evaluation metrics.
The analysis is primarily quantitative. There is limited subjective context or interpretation beyond describing the results.
No qualitative data coding or analysis is described.
Results are presented in tables (Table 2) and figures (Fig. 2, Fig. 3, Fig. 4, Fig. 5, Fig. 6) with clear labels and descriptions.
Section 5.1 explicitly discusses study limitations, including computational resource constraints, the number of repetitions in the evaluation, and the focus on tabular data.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
